elements.content: A Rhodamine B (RhB) dye coordinated, 2D metal–organic framework (MOF), {[Zn2(L)­(RhB)]·5DMF} n (1; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), was constructed solvothermally from a −NH2-functionalized ligand and ZnII ions. The MOF features interlayer π···π interaction between the RhB molecules with an overlap of almost 100%. One- and two-photon-excited fluorescence measurements were carried out on micrometer-sized single crystals of varied thickness with continuous-wave and femtosecond pulsed lasers, respectively. The two-photon absorption coefficient was measured relative to the CdS crystal and found to be 7.1 ± 0.7 cm/GW at a wavelength of 1030 nm. Our findings demonstrate a new way of achieving solid-state dye microlasers or microsized light-frequency upconverters.
elements.clean_text: A Rhodamine B (RhB) dye coordinated, 2D metal-organic framework (MOF), {[Zn2(L)(RhB)]⋅5DMF} n  (1; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), was constructed solvothermally from a -NH2-functionalized ligand and ZnII ions. The MOF features interlayer π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the RhB molecules with an overlap of almost 100%. One- and two-photon-excited fluorescence measurements were carried out on micrometer-sized single crystals of varied thickness with continuous-wave and femtosecond pulsed lasers, respectively. The two-photon absorption coefficient was measured relative to the CdS crystal and found to be 7.1 ± 0.7 cm/GW at a wavelength of 1030 nm. Our findings demonstrate a new way of achieving solid-state dye microlasers or microsized light-frequency upconverters.

elements.content: The past few years have witnessed a great upsurge of interest in two-photon fluorescence (TPF) materials because of their diverse applications in biological imaging and two-photon-pumped (TPP) upconversion lasing. Unlike conventional single-photon emission, it is possible to observe TPF at a much longer excitation wavelength up to the red or near-infrared (NIR) spectral region. This low-photon-energy excitation requirement enables the fabrication of semiconductor diode lasers to significantly enhance the photostability of materials. The TPF phenomenon has been demonstrated in several organic dyes such as Rhodamine 6G, Rhodamine B (RhB), 4-(dicyanomethylene)-2-methyl-6-(4-dimethylaminostyryl)-4H-pyran, and pyridinium hemicyanine that offer several advantages in optical imaging, including the use of minimally toxic NIR light, labeling without the need for genetic intervention, rapid kinetics, and long persistence of a photoconverted signal. However, the major disadvantage of these dyes is that it can only be realized in dilute solutions. Furthermore, the aggregation-caused quenching in these dyes in the solid state has seriously limited the development of solid-state TPP upconversion lasers.
elements.clean_text: The past few years have witnessed a great upsurge of interest in two-photon fluorescence (TPF) materials because of their diverse applications in biological imaging and two-photon-pumped (TPP) upconversion lasing. Unlike conventional single-photon emission, it is possible to observe TPF at a much longer excitation wavelength up to the red or near-infrared (NIR) spectral region. This low-photon-energy excitation requirement enables the fabrication of semiconductor diode lasers to significantly enhance the photostability of materials. The TPF phenomenon has been demonstrated in several organic dyes such as Rhodamine 6G, Rhodamine B (RhB), 4-(dicyanomethylene)-2-methyl-6-(4-dimethylaminostyryl)-4H-pyran, and pyridinium hemicyanine that offer several advantages in optical imaging, including the use of minimally toxic NIR light, labeling without the need for genetic intervention, rapid kinetics, and long persistence of a photoconverted signal. However, the major disadvantage of these dyes is that it can only be realized in dilute solutions. Furthermore, the aggregation-caused quenching in these dyes in the solid state has seriously limited the development of solid-state TPP upconversion lasers.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been intensively explored as a new type of multifunctional luminescent material. Recently, multiphoton absorption studies have also been investigated in MOFs. Until now, only two reports appeared in which TPF has been observed from single crystals of MOFs, whereas others have been observed from MOF powders. Yu et al. demonstrated the immobilization of a cationic pyridinium hemicyanine dye, 4-[p-(dimethylamino)­styryl]-1-methylpyridinium, into the pores of bio-MOF-1 single crystals, which show efficient TPF. However, dye uptake in the single crystals can be achieved only up to 40% through the postsynthetic modification method. A more efficient strategy could be the direct coordination of a laser dye in the MOF structure, which can result in nearly 100% containment of the dye into the MOF structure. Avoiding of dye molecule aggregation in the MOF matrix is another important criterion for the efficiency of a desired application. For example, the formation of H and J dimers induces blue and red shifts, respectively, in molecular aggregates. Similarly, the presence of aggregates may also give rise to fluorescence quenching at high concentration. Here, we explore a strategy of coordinating laser dye RhB molecules in a MOF.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been intensively explored as a new type of multifunctional luminescent material. Recently, multiphoton absorption studies have also been investigated in MOFs. Until now, only two reports appeared in which TPF has been observed from single crystals of MOFs, whereas others have been observed from MOF powders. Yu et al. demonstrated the immobilization of a cationic pyridinium hemicyanine dye, 4-[p-(dimethylamino)styryl]-1-methylpyridinium, into the pores of bio-MOF-1 single crystals, which show efficient TPF. However, dye uptake in the single crystals can be achieved only up to 40% through the postsynthetic modification method. A more efficient strategy could be the direct coordination of a laser dye in the MOF structure, which can result in nearly 100% containment of the dye into the MOF structure. Avoiding of dye molecule aggregation in the MOF matrix is another important criterion for the efficiency of a desired application. For example, the formation of H and J dimers induces blue and red shifts, respectively, in molecular aggregates. Similarly, the presence of aggregates may also give rise to fluorescence quenching at high concentration. Here, we explore a strategy of coordinating laser dye RhB molecules in a MOF.

elements.content: Among the lasing dyes, we have chosen RhB having a free −COOH group for metal coordination besides showing a high two-photon absorption (TPA) cross section as well as fluorescence even in the dimeric state. RhB and its derivatives also have long-wavelength absorption and emission range, high quantum efficiency, and good photostability.
elements.clean_text: Among the lasing dyes, we have chosen RhB having a free -COOH group for metal coordination besides showing a high two-photon absorption (TPA) cross section as well as fluorescence even in the dimeric state. RhB and its derivatives also have long-wavelength absorption and emission range, high quantum efficiency, and good photostability.

elements.content: RhB has been used extensively in industrial coloration, as biomarkers, and as a fluorometric probe. Herein, we report a RhB-coordinated ZnII-MOF, which is capable of showing the TPF phenomenon in single crystals. The reaction of ZnII ions, RhB, and an amine-functionalized carboxylate ligand resulted in a MOF structure, {[Zn2(L)­(RhB)]·5DMF} n (1; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), where L is a −NH2-functionalized tetracarboxylate ligand and RhB is a Rhodamine B dye (). The −NH2 functional group has been chosen in ligand L, so as to facilitate intramolecular charge transfer between electron-donating −NH2 and electron-withdrawing −COOH groups which is a prerequisite for the large nonlinear-optical response.
elements.clean_text: RhB has been used extensively in industrial coloration, as biomarkers, and as a fluorometric probe. Herein, we report a RhB-coordinated ZnII-MOF, which is capable of showing the TPF phenomenon in single crystals. The reaction of ZnII ions, RhB, and an amine-functionalized carboxylate ligand resulted in a MOF structure, {[Zn2(L)(RhB)]⋅5DMF} n  (1; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), where L is a -NH2-functionalized tetracarboxylate ligand and RhB is a Rhodamine B dye (). The -NH2 functional group has been chosen in ligand L, so as to facilitate intramolecular charge transfer between electron-donating -NH2 and electron-withdrawing -COOH groups which is a prerequisite for the large nonlinear-optical response.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Diagram Showing the Geometry of Ligand H4L and RhB To Form 1

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction of Zn­(NO3)2 with H4L and RhB in DMF for 3 days afforded dark-red crystals of 1 (see the Supporting Information, SI). Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that 1 crystallized in the orthorhombic space group Pbca, with the asymmetric unit consisting of two ZnII ions, one L, and one RhB molecule along with five DMF molecules in the lattice. The Zn1 and Zn2 ions formed a dinuclear center coordinated to four carboxylate groups of L and one carboxylate group of RhB with a Zn···Zn separation of 3.447 Å. Coordination of the linker L and ZnII ion resulted in a 2D sheet structure decorated with dye molecules above and below the sheet structure, as depicted in b. Detailed structural inspection revealed that the RhB dye molecules of the two adjacent layers made face-to-face aromatic interactions in an antiparallel fashion with a distance of 3.533 Å between the centroids of the aromatic rings, suggesting strong π···π interactions (a). The molecular geometry of RhB () revealed that it was a nonsymmetric molecule. However, careful inspection of the crystal structure showed that all of the bond distances of RhB were nearly equal. This suggested a high π-electron delocalization in the RhB molecule in the MOF 1.
elements.clean_text: The solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2 with H4L and RhB in DMF for 3 days afforded dark-red crystals of 1 (see the Supporting Information, SI). Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that 1 crystallized in the orthorhombic space group Pbca, with the asymmetric unit consisting of two ZnII ions, one L, and one RhB molecule along with five DMF molecules in the lattice. The Zn1 and Zn2 ions formed a dinuclear center coordinated to four carboxylate groups of L and one carboxylate group of RhB with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation of 3.447 Å. Coordination of the linker L and ZnII ion resulted in a 2D sheet structure decorated with dye molecules above and below the sheet structure, as depicted in b. Detailed structural inspection revealed that the RhB dye molecules of the two adjacent layers made face-to-face aromatic interactions in an antiparallel fashion with a distance of 3.533 Å between the centroids of the aromatic rings, suggesting strong π⋅⋅⋅π interactions (a). The molecular geometry of RhB () revealed that it was a nonsymmetric molecule. However, careful inspection of the crystal structure showed that all of the bond distances of RhB were nearly equal. This suggested a high π-electron delocalization in the RhB molecule in the MOF 1.

elements.content: (a) ZnII coordination environment with L and the coordinated RhB dye molecule in 1 and (b) 2D sheet structure of 1, where RhB molecules have been omitted for clarity and shown by violet spheres.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) ZnII coordination environment with L and the coordinated RhB dye molecule in 1 and (b) 2D sheet structure of 1, where RhB molecules have been omitted for clarity and shown by violet spheres.

elements.content: (a) Face-to-face π···π interactions between the RhB molecules. Photographic images of 1 recorded with a fluorescence microscope (b) under a xenon lamp, (c) at λex = 358 nm, and (d) at λex = 542 nm.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the RhB molecules. Photographic images of 1 recorded with a fluorescence microscope (b) under a xenon lamp, (c) at λex = 358 nm, and (d) at λex = 542 nm.

elements.content: A view of a single crystal of 1 under a xenon lamp is displayed in b, and photographic images under light with excitation wavelengths of λex = 358 and 542 nm are shown in parts c and d of , respectively. An optical microscope with suitable bandpass filters [358 nm with full width at half-maximum (fwhm) = 13 nm and 542 nm with fwhm = 27 nm] and a charge-coupled device (CCD) was used to acquire these images. These images revealed that 1 showed an intense blue color upon excitation at 358 nm and a bright-yellow color upon excitation at 542 nm. Such a distinct naked-eye dual fluorescence in MOF crystals being an uncommon phenomenon could be attributed to the presence of a highly fluorescent RhB molecule in 1. Notably, the blue fluorescence was assignable to ligand L and the yellow fluorescence to the RhB molecule in 1.
elements.clean_text: A view of a single crystal of 1 under a xenon lamp is displayed in b, and photographic images under light with excitation wavelengths of λex = 358 and 542 nm are shown in parts c and d of , respectively. An optical microscope with suitable bandpass filters [358 nm with full width at half-maximum (fwhm) = 13 nm and 542 nm with fwhm = 27 nm] and a charge-coupled device (CCD) was used to acquire these images. These images revealed that 1 showed an intense blue color upon excitation at 358 nm and a bright-yellow color upon excitation at 542 nm. Such a distinct naked-eye dual fluorescence in MOF crystals being an uncommon phenomenon could be attributed to the presence of a highly fluorescent RhB molecule in 1. Notably, the blue fluorescence was assignable to ligand L and the yellow fluorescence to the RhB molecule in 1.

elements.content: To establish the effect of the coordinated RhB dye, the emission spectra of three different forms (powder, solution, and MOF crystal) were examined, as shown in . A large red shift in the emission peak between the solution (λem = 570 nm) and powder (λem = 710 nm) was observed that could be attributed to the presence of higher molecular aggregates of RhB in the powder form. A red shift between the emission peaks of RhB in solution and MOF crystal was also observed, attributable to the highly rigid form of coordinated RhB in 1 that prohibited nonradiative decay. Furthermore, the emission peak of 1 appeared at 675 nm, which was blue-shifted by 35 nm compared to RhB in the form of powder. This small blue shift in 1 was due to the dimeric form of RhB, which showed strong π···π interaction in the crystal structure.

Furthermore, the emission peak of 1 appeared at 675 nm, which was blue-shifted by 35 nm compared to RhB in the form of powder. This small blue shift in 1 was due to the dimeric form of RhB, which showed strong π⋅⋅⋅π interaction in the crystal structure.

elements.content: A commercial microscope setup (Nikon, Eclipse Ti-2) (Scheme S2) was employed to conduct one-photon fluorescence (OPF), TPF, and time-resolved TPF measurements. The details on the different measurements can be found in Table S1. Linear- and nonlinear-optical measurements on the crystals of 1 were carried out using the above-mentioned setup without using the half-wave plate along the beam path. OPF experiments were conducted on single crystals of three different thicknesses (20, 26, and 30 μm) under a continuous-wave laser excitation at λex = 403 nm with varying power density. shows the emission spectrum from a 30-μm-thick crystal as an example (see Figure S11 for more results on 20- and 26-μm-thick crystals). The log–log plot of integrated fluorescence versus excitation power density, given as the inset, afforded a value of 1.0 for the slope, implying the involvement of one-photon absorption (OPA) process.
elements.clean_text: A commercial microscope setup (Nikon, Eclipse Ti-2) (Scheme S2) was employed to conduct one-photon fluorescence (OPF), TPF, and time-resolved TPF measurements. The details on the different measurements can be found in Table S1. OPF experiments were conducted on single crystals of three different thicknesses (20, 26, and 30 μm) under a continuous-wave laser excitation at λex = 403 nm with varying power density.  shows the emission spectrum from a 30-μm-thick crystal as an example (see Figure S11 for more results on 20- and 26-μm-thick crystals). The log-log plot of integrated fluorescence versus excitation power density, given as the inset, afforded a value of 1.0 for the slope, implying the involvement of one-photon absorption (OPA) process.

elements.content: One-photon-excited emission of a single crystal of 1 (30 μm) under an excitation wavelength of 403 nm with varying excitation power density.
elements.clean_text: 4  One-photon-excited emission of a single crystal of 1 (30 μm) under an excitation wavelength of 403 nm with varying excitation power density.

elements.content: TPF was measured on 1 with excitation of femtosecond laser pulses [wavelength = 1030 nm, pulse width (fwhm) = 150 fs, and repetition rate = 1 MHz]. Single crystals of 1 having different thicknesses (20, 26, and 30 μm) were examined. The average excitation power was chosen in such a way that neither damage to the sample nor signal saturation occurred. Parts a–c of provide the TPF spectra collected under varying excitation power densities. Because the excitation wavelength was at 1030 nm (NIR region) and the emission spanned from 600 to 800 nm, this indicated that the excitation mechanism involved was not OPA but the simultaneous absorption of two photons. The three insets show the log–log plots of integrated photoluminescence (PL) versus excitation power density, giving straight lines with a slope of ∼2 (and an error of 5%). These confirmed that the excitation process involved was TPA. White light (halogen lamp) was illuminated on these crystals of 1, and the corresponding CCD images of different thicknesses were recorded as displayed in the insets. Normalized OPF and TPF signals are shown in d for comparison. The peak of TPF was slightly blue-shifted by 0.02 eV, and the fwhm was also reduced from 0.22 eV (OPF) to 0.19 eV (TPF).

Single crystals of 1 having different thicknesses (20, 26, and 30 μm) were examined. The average excitation power was chosen in such a way that neither damage to the sample nor signal saturation occurred. Parts a-c of  provide the TPF spectra collected under varying excitation power densities. Because the excitation wavelength was at 1030 nm (NIR region) and the emission spanned from 600 to 800 nm, this indicated that the excitation mechanism involved was not OPA but the simultaneous absorption of two photons. The three insets show the log-log plots of integrated photoluminescence (PL) versus excitation power density, giving straight lines with a slope of ~2 (and an error of 5%). These confirmed that the excitation process involved was TPA. White light (halogen lamp) was illuminated on these crystals of 1, and the corresponding CCD images of different thicknesses were recorded as displayed in the insets. Normalized OPF and TPF signals are shown in d for comparison. The peak of TPF was slightly blue-shifted by 0.02 eV, and the fwhm was also reduced from 0.22 eV (OPF) to 0.19 eV (TPF).

elements.content: (a–c) TPF measurements on single crystals of 1 for three different thicknesses (20, 26 and 30 μm) with an excitation wavelength of 1030 nm under varying excitation power density. The CCD images of the crystals are shown, and the blue spot represents the excitation region (the diameter is 4 μm). All scale bars are 10 μm. (d) Comparison of OPF and TPF. TPF is slightly blue-shifted by 0.02 eV related to OPF.

TPF is slightly blue-shifted by 0.02 eV related to OPF.

elements.content: We have also carried out a comparison of the OPF and TPF studies in different solvents, namely, methanol, ethanol, acetone, and chloroform. As depicted in Figure S15, no significant changes in the wavelengths of different solvent-exchanged crystals of 1 were found in either one- or two-photon emission spectra (Table S4).
elements.clean_text: We have also carried out a comparison of the OPF and TPF studies in different solvents, namely, methanol, ethanol, acetone, and chloroform. As depicted in Figure S15, no significant changes in the wavelengths of different solvent-exchanged crystals of 1 were found in either one- or two-photon emission spectra (Table S4).

elements.content: Time-resolved TPF measurements were also performed to determine the excited-state lifetime using the time-correlated single-photon-counting method. Three spots were randomly selected (a) on a single crystal of 1 (thickness ∼26 μm) for the measurements. The decay time (for 0° polarization excitation) for three different spots were found to be (32 ± 3) × 10, (32 ± 3) × 10, and (33 ± 3) × 10 ps, which were ∼10 times smaller than the radiative decay time of the RhB solution in an acetonitrile solvent. (see the SI for a detailed calculation of the decay time of spots 1–3). The reduction of the TPF lifetime of RhB in the MOF was due to an efficient energy transfer, which was ensured by the presence of the ligand L. Furthermore, the excitation power and polarization dependence of time-resolved TPF were also investigated. The polarization dependence of time-resolved TPF measurements were done by employing an additional half-wave plate in the setup (Scheme S2). b shows the normalized time-resolved TPF signals for various laser excitation powers. Parts c and d of show the polarization-resolved TPF decay time for a laser excitation density of 63 GW/cm2. The polar plot shown in c reveals an isotropic decay time for crystal 1. These measurements showed that the decay time was independent of both the excitation power and polarization of the laser beam.
elements.clean_text: Time-resolved TPF measurements were also performed to determine the excited-state lifetime using the time-correlated single-photon-counting method. Three spots were randomly selected (a) on a single crystal of 1 (thickness ~26 μm) for the measurements. The decay time (for 0° polarization excitation) for three different spots were found to be (32 ± 3) × 10, (32 ± 3) × 10, and (33 ± 3) × 10 ps, which were ~10 times smaller than the radiative decay time of the RhB solution in an acetonitrile solvent. (see the SI for a detailed calculation of the decay time of spots 1-3). The reduction of the TPF lifetime of RhB in the MOF was due to an efficient energy transfer, which was ensured by the presence of the ligand L. Furthermore, the excitation power and polarization dependence of time-resolved TPF were also investigated. The polarization dependence of time-resolved TPF measurements were done by employing an additional half-wave plate in the setup (Scheme S2). b shows the normalized time-resolved TPF signals for various laser excitation powers. Parts c and d of  show the polarization-resolved TPF decay time for a laser excitation density of 63 GW/cm2. The polar plot shown in c reveals an isotropic decay time for crystal 1. These measurements showed that the decay time was independent of both the excitation power and polarization of the laser beam.

elements.content: (a) Three different spots that were considered, as indicated by blue circles. The crystal thickness is 26 μm. (b) TPF count on a logarithmic scale for different excitation peak power densities for spot 1. All curves are overlapping each other, indicating that the TPF decay time is power-independent. (c) Plot of TPPL decay time versus excitation polarization. No significant polarization dependence was observed. (d) TPF count on a logarithmic scale for different excitation polarizations on spot 1 at a peak power density of 63.6 GW/cm2.

(c) Plot of TPPL decay time versus excitation polarization. No significant polarization dependence was observed. (d) TPF count on a logarithmic scale for different excitation polarizations on spot 1 at a peak power density of 63.6 GW/cm2.

elements.content: The TPF efficiency of a crystal of 1 could be determined by comparison to a standard material. The two-photon action cross section (ηβ), where η denotes the fluorescence quantum efficiency and β the TPA coefficient, gave a direct measure of the TPF efficiency. The action cross section could be found using the equation #PL MOF #PL standard = ( η β ) MOF I MOF 2 L MOF ( η β ) standard I standard 2 × 2 z 0 where #PLMOF/#PLstandard refers to the fluorescence signal strength for the MOF or standard material detected by the spectrometer, η is the fluorescence quantum efficiency, β is the TPA coefficient, I is the incident beam intensity, L is the MOF crystal thickness, and z 0 is the Rayleigh length of the focused laser beam having a Gaussian profile.
elements.clean_text: The TPF efficiency of a crystal of 1 could be determined by comparison to a standard material. The two-photon action cross section (ηβ), where η denotes the fluorescence quantum efficiency and β the TPA coefficient, gave a direct measure of the TPF efficiency. The action cross section could be found using the equation 1         #PL   MOF       #PL   standard     =     ( η β )   MOF      I   MOF    2     L   MOF       ( η β )   standard      I   standard    2   × 2   z   0        where #PLMOF/#PLstandard refers to the fluorescence signal strength for the MOF or standard material detected by the spectrometer, η is the fluorescence quantum efficiency, β is the TPA coefficient, I is the incident beam intensity, L is the MOF crystal thickness, and z 0 is the Rayleigh length of the focused laser beam having a Gaussian profile.

elements.content: The two-photon action cross section, ηβ, was measured relative to a standard crystal of CdS (thickness ∼1 mm). The quantum efficiency (η) and TPA coefficient (β) of the CdS crystal are 0.01 and 6.4 cm/GW, respectively. The Rayleigh length of the excitation Gaussian beam was found to be 12 μm (for 1030 nm). Because the thickness of the CdS crystal was 1 mm, which was far greater than the Rayleigh length of the excitation beam, TPF of CdS was considered to occur within a length of 2z 0. By using , the value of ηβ for a crystal of 1 (thickness∼ 30 μm) was found to be 7.1 ± 0.72 cm/GW. This value was 1 order greater than that of the CdS crystal. Such a large action cross section was attributed to the presence of large voids within the MOF unit cell (∼47%), preventing RhB from aggregation-induced fluorescence quenching, as was the case for tightly arranged organic crystals formed from molecular chromophores. It was also suggested that restriction of the intramolecular rotation of the chromophore molecule in a rigid structure can enhance the TPF efficiency. Because RhB molecules themselves acted as spatially confined ligands, their intramolecular rotations were limited, which facilitated a large value of the two-photon action cross section. Such a 2D-layered MOF crystal with a large ηβ value should possess great potential for solid-state dye microlasers or microsized light-frequency upconverters.
elements.clean_text: The two-photon action cross section, ηβ, was measured relative to a standard crystal of CdS (thickness ~1 mm). The quantum efficiency (η) and TPA coefficient (β) of the CdS crystal are 0.01 and 6.4 cm/GW, respectively. The Rayleigh length of the excitation Gaussian beam was found to be 12 μm (for 1030 nm). Because the thickness of the CdS crystal was 1 mm, which was far greater than the Rayleigh length of the excitation beam, TPF of CdS was considered to occur within a length of 2z 0. By using , the value of ηβ for a crystal of 1 (thickness~ 30 μm) was found to be 7.1 ± 0.72 cm/GW. This value was 1 order greater than that of the CdS crystal. Such a large action cross section was attributed to the presence of large voids within the MOF unit cell (~47%), preventing RhB from aggregation-induced fluorescence quenching, as was the case for tightly arranged organic crystals formed from molecular chromophores. It was also suggested that restriction of the intramolecular rotation of the chromophore molecule in a rigid structure can enhance the TPF efficiency. Because RhB molecules themselves acted as spatially confined ligands, their intramolecular rotations were limited, which facilitated a large value of the two-photon action cross section. Such a 2D-layered MOF crystal with a large ηβ value should possess great potential for solid-state dye microlasers or microsized light-frequency upconverters.

elements.content: The thermal stability of 1 was investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figure S9). TGA revealed a loss of DMF solvent molecules up to ∼260 °C and decomposition of the framework could be achieved only beyond ∼400 °C. Further stability studies were performed using variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD; Figure S10a,b). PXRD of the as-synthesized and simulated patterns matched well, suggesting phase purity of the bulk sample. Furthermore, VT-PXRD analysis suggested the sample retained its crystallinity at least up to 200 °C. The porosity of 1 was further examined by N2 gas sorption measurement. As shown in Figure S16, the N2 gas adsorption measurement at 77 K and 1 atm revealed a type I isotherm with a maximum uptake of 79.9 cm3/g (STP) corresponding to a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 263 m2/g.
elements.clean_text: The thermal stability of 1 was investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figure S9). TGA revealed a loss of DMF solvent molecules up to ~260 °C and decomposition of the framework could be achieved only beyond ~400 °C. Further stability studies were performed using variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD; Figure S10a,b). PXRD of the as-synthesized and simulated patterns matched well, suggesting phase purity of the bulk sample. Furthermore, VT-PXRD analysis suggested the sample retained its crystallinity at least up to 200 °C. The porosity of 1 was further examined by N2 gas sorption measurement. As shown in Figure S16, the N2 gas adsorption measurement at 77 K and 1 atm revealed a type I isotherm with a maximum uptake of 79.9 cm3/g (STP) corresponding to a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 263 m2/g.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have designed and demonstrated a novel type of micrometer-sized MOF with the incorporation of RhB dye molecule as the coordinating organic ligand and investigated the enhancement in TPF efficiency of these MOF crystals. In contrast to the aggregation-induced fluorescence quenching in solid-state organic dyes, the RhB-coordinated network in 1 exhibits a highly efficient TPF with an action cross section of 7.1 ± 0.72 cm/GW. Restriction of the intramolecular rotation of RhB molecules, combined with the presence of a large void in the framework, resulted in such an efficient TPF. Thus, MOF 1 promises to be a suitable candidate as a cost-effective luminescent material in solid-state form for many photonic applications. Our synthesis approach also promises a systematic realization of highly luminescent MOF crystals by the rational choice of dye molecules with the coordinating ability to the MOF framework. Such MOF crystals with large two-photon action cross section values should possess great potential for solid-state dye microlasers or microsized light-frequency upconverters.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have designed and demonstrated a novel type of micrometer-sized MOF with the incorporation of RhB dye molecule as the coordinating organic ligand and investigated the enhancement in TPF efficiency of these MOF crystals. In contrast to the aggregation-induced fluorescence quenching in solid-state organic dyes, the RhB-coordinated network in 1 exhibits a highly efficient TPF with an action cross section of 7.1 ± 0.72 cm/GW. Restriction of the intramolecular rotation of RhB molecules, combined with the presence of a large void in the framework, resulted in such an efficient TPF. Thus, MOF 1 promises to be a suitable candidate as a cost-effective luminescent material in solid-state form for many photonic applications. Our synthesis approach also promises a systematic realization of highly luminescent MOF crystals by the rational choice of dye molecules with the coordinating ability to the MOF framework. Such MOF crystals with large two-photon action cross section values should possess great potential for solid-state dye microlasers or microsized light-frequency upconverters.

cln_elements.content: The thermal stability of 1 was investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figure S9). TGA revealed a loss of DMF solvent molecules up to ∼260 °C and decomposition of the framework could be achieved only beyond ∼400 °C. Further stability studies were performed using variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD; Figure S10a,b). PXRD of the as-synthesized and simulated patterns matched well, suggesting phase purity of the bulk sample. Furthermore, VT-PXRD analysis suggested the sample retained its crystallinity at least up to 200 °C. The porosity of 1 was further examined by N2 gas sorption measurement. As shown in Figure S16, the N2 gas adsorption measurement at 77 K and 1 atm revealed a type I isotherm with a maximum uptake of 79.9 cm3/g (STP) corresponding to a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 263 m2/g.
cln_elements.clean_text: The thermal stability of 1 was investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figure S9). TGA revealed a loss of DMF solvent molecules up to ~260 °C and decomposition of the framework could be achieved only beyond ~400 °C. Further stability studies were performed using variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD; Figure S10a,b). PXRD of the as-synthesized and simulated patterns matched well, suggesting phase purity of the bulk sample. Furthermore, VT-PXRD analysis suggested the sample retained its crystallinity at least up to 200 °C. The porosity of 1 was further examined by N2 gas sorption measurement. As shown in Figure S16, the N2 gas adsorption measurement at 77 K and 1 atm revealed a type I isotherm with a maximum uptake of 79.9 cm3/g (STP) corresponding to a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 263 m2/g.

cln_elements.content: (a–c) TPF measurements on single crystals of 1 for three different thicknesses (20, 26 and 30 μm) with an excitation wavelength of 1030 nm under varying excitation power density. The CCD images of the crystals are shown, and the blue spot represents the excitation region (the diameter is 4 μm). All scale bars are 10 μm. (d) Comparison of OPF and TPF. TPF is slightly blue-shifted by 0.02 eV related to OPF.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  (a-c) TPF measurements on single crystals of 1 for three different thicknesses (20, 26 and 30 μm) with an excitation wavelength of 1030 nm under varying excitation power density. The CCD images of the crystals are shown, and the blue spot represents the excitation region (the diameter is 4 μm). All scale bars are 10 μm. (d) Comparison of OPF and TPF. TPF is slightly blue-shifted by 0.02 eV related to OPF.

cln_elements.content: (a) Three different spots that were considered, as indicated by blue circles. The crystal thickness is 26 μm. (b) TPF count on a logarithmic scale for different excitation peak power densities for spot 1. All curves are overlapping each other, indicating that the TPF decay time is power-independent. (c) Plot of TPPL decay time versus excitation polarization. No significant polarization dependence was observed. (d) TPF count on a logarithmic scale for different excitation polarizations on spot 1 at a peak power density of 63.6 GW/cm2.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Three different spots that were considered, as indicated by blue circles. The crystal thickness is 26 μm. (c) Plot of TPPL decay time versus excitation polarization. No significant polarization dependence was observed. metadata.title:
Two-Photon Absorption and Fluorescence in Micrometer-Sized
Single Crystals of a Rhodamine B Coordinated Metal–Organic
Framework
